folder: Kingsbridge Road (We & Heath Avenue, Bronx, NY
text:
W. Kingsbridge Road, south from Heath Avenue, up "Breakneck Hill" toward Sedgwick Avenue. Mr. Randall Comfort, historian of the Bronx, states that it is an old lane at Kingsbridge, which was part of a colonial highway that led up from Spuyten Duyvil Creek across the steep "Breakneck Hill" to Fordham and West Farms. It follows the course of the old King's Bridge Road which led from Manhattan over King's Bridge (now 230th Street at Kingsbridge Avenue), and another branch of which led over Farmer's Bridge (now W. Kingsbridge Road, directly west of Exterior Street) across the entire breadth of the Bronx, through Fordham and West Farms, then across the Bronx River at E. 180th Street, into Westchester County. King's Bridge Road, in older times, was the Boston Post Road, and it is possible that this is part of the road along which Mrs. Knight, mentioned in Wells's history of the Bronx (p. 315), traveled.

1906.

Gift of Randall Comfort.

A general view westward from West Kingsbridge Road, below Heath Ave., showing, in the background the Harlem River and the Broadway bridge connecting Manhattan with the Bronx. Across the bridge, on the right is the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx, and on the left, Inwood Hill Park, Manhattan.

October 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, another view. In the center of the view is discernible the oval New York Velodrome.

October 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: General View - Bronx - Kingsbridge Road below Heath Avenue.
